documentation: <fullname>OpsWorks</fullname>  <!-- JEN: Is 'Service' really part of the name? Guysm: Dunno. It was in the original file.-->

CloneStack.name: CloneStack

Region.documentation: The cloned stack AWS region, such as "us-east-1". For more information about AWS regions, see Regions and Endpoints

Attributes.documentation: A list of stack attributes and values as key/value pairs to be added to the cloned stack.

ServiceRoleArn.documentation: The stack AWS Identity and Access Management (IAM) role, which allows OpsWorks to work with AWS resources on your behalf. You must set this parameter to the Amazon Resource Name (ARN) for an existing IAM role. If you create a stack by using the OpsWorks console, it creates the role for you. You can obtain an existing stack's IAM ARN programmatically by calling DescribePermissions. For more information about IAM ARNs, see Using Identifiers.

DefaultOs.documentation:
The cloned stack default operating system, which must be one of the following:

  • m1.small
  • m1.medium
  • m1.large
  • m1.xlarge
  • c1.medium
  • c1.xlarge
  • m2.xlarge
  • m2.2xlarge
  • m2.4xlarge

HostnameTheme.documentation: The cloned stack host name theme, with spaces replaced by underscores. For example: Bud_Spencer. OpsWorks uses this string to generate host names for the stack instances.

DefaultAvailabilityZone.documentation: The cloned stack Availability Zone. For more information, see Regions and Endpoints.

CustomJson.documentation:
A string that contains user-defined, custom JSON. It is used to override the corresponding default stack configuration JSON values. The string should be in the following format and must escape characters such as '"'.:

"{\"key1\": \"value1\", \"key2\": \"value2\",...}"

Url.documentation:
The source URI. For example, the source URI for the OpsWorks MySQL cookbook is: https://github.com/scalarium/cookbooks.git

For Github repositories, you can also use the "git://..." format. For example:

git://github.com/scalarium/cookbooks.git

Revision.documentation: The application's version. OpsWorks enables you to easily deploy new versions of an application. One of the simplest approaches is to have branches or revisions in your repository that represent different versions that can potentially be deployed.

DefaultSshKeyName.documentation: A default SSH key for the stack instances. You can override this value when you create or update an instance.

ClonePermissions.documentation: Whether to clone the source stack's permissions.

CloneAppIds.documentation: A list of source stack app IDs to be included in the cloned stack.

errors.documentation: Indicates that a resource was not found.

CloneStack.documentation: Creates a clone of a specified stack.

CreateApp.name: CreateApp

Type.documentation: The app type. Each supported type is associated with a particular layer. For example, PHP applications are associated with a PHP layer. OpsWorks deploys an application to those instances that are members of the corresponding layer.

Url.documentation:
The source URI. For example, the source URI for the OpsWorks MySQL cookbook is: https://github.com/scalarium/cookbooks.git

For Github repositories, you can also use the "git://..." format. For example:

git://github.com/scalarium/cookbooks.git

Revision.documentation: The application's version. OpsWorks enables you to easily deploy new versions of an application. One of the simplest approaches is to have branches or revisions in your repository that represent different versions that can potentially be deployed.

AppSource.documentation: A Source object that specifies the app repository.

Domains.documentation: The app virtual host settings, with multiple domains separated by commas. For example: 'www.mysite.com, mysite.com'

EnableSsl.documentation: Whether to enable SSL for the app.

Certificate.documentation: The contents of the certificate's domain.crt file.

PrivateKey.documentation: The private key; the contents of the certificate's domain.kex file.

Chain.documentation: Optional. Can be used to specify an intermediate certificate authority key or client authentication.

Attributes.documentation: One or more user-defined key/value pairs to be added to the stack attributes bag.

errors.documentation: Indicates that a resource was not found.

CreateApp.documentation: Creates an app for a specified stack.

CreateDeployment.name: CreateDeployment

InstanceIds.documentation: The instance IDs for the deployment targets.

Name.documentation:
Specifies the deployment operation. You can specify only one command.

For stacks, the available commands are:

  • ExecuteRecipes: Execute the recipes that are specified by the Args parameter.
  • InstallDependencies: Installs the stack's dependencies.
  • UpdateCustomCookbooks: Update the stack's custom cookbooks.
  • UpdateDependencies: Update the stack's dependencies.

For apps, the available commands are:

  • DeployApp: Deploy the app.
  • RollbackApp Roll the app back to the previous version. When you update an app, OpsWorks stores the previous version, up to a maximum of five versions. You can use this command to roll an app back as many as four versions.
  • StartApp: Start the app's web or application server.
  • StopApp: Stop the app's web or application server.
  • UndeployApp: Undeploy the app.

Args.documentation: An array of command arguments. This parameter is currently used only to specify the list of recipes to be executed by the ExecuteRecipes command.

Command.documentation: A DeploymentCommand object that describes details of the operation.

CustomJson.documentation:
A string that contains user-defined, custom JSON. It is used to override the corresponding default stack configuration JSON values. The string should be in the following format and must escape characters such as '"'.:

"{\"key1\": \"value1\", \"key2\": \"value2\",...}"

DeploymentId.documentation: The deployment ID, which can be used with other requests to identify the deployment.

errors.documentation: Indicates that a resource was not found.

CreateDeployment.documentation:
Deploys a stack or app.

  • App deployment generates a deploy event, which runs the associated recipes and passes them a JSON stack configuration object that includes information about the app.
  • Stack deployment runs the deploy recipes but does not raise an event.

CreateInstance.name: CreateInstance

LayerIds.documentation: An array that contains the instance layer IDs.

InstanceType.documentation:
The instance type, which can be one of the following:

  • m1.small
  • m1.medium
  • m1.large
  • m1.xlarge
  • c1.medium
  • c1.xlarge
  • m2.xlarge
  • m2.2xlarge
  • m2.4xlarge

AutoScalingType.documentation:
The instance auto scaling type, which has three possible values:

  • AlwaysRunning: A 24x7 instance, which is not affected by auto scaling.
  • TimeBasedAutoScaling: A time-based auto scaling instance, which is started and stopped based on a specified schedule. To specify the schedule, call SetTimeBasedAutoScaling.
  • LoadBasedAutoScaling: A load-based auto scaling instance, which is started and stopped based on load metrics. To use load-based auto scaling, you must enable it for the instance layer and configure the thresholds by calling SetLoadBasedAutoScaling.

AvailabilityZone.documentation: The instance Availability Zone. For more information, see Regions and Endpoints.

CreateInstance.documentation: Creates an instance in a specified stack.

Type.documentation: The layer type. A stack cannot have more than one layer of the same type.

Name.documentation: The layer name, which is used by the console.

Shortname.documentation: The layer short name, which is used internally by OpsWorks and by Chef recipes. The shortname is also used as the name for the directory where your app files are installed. It can have a maximum of 200 characters, which are limited to the alphanumeric characters, '-', '_', and '.'.

Attributes.documentation: One or more user-defined key/value pairs to be added to the stack attributes bag.

InstanceProfileArn.documentation: An IAM profile ARN for the layer instances. You can override this value when you create an instance. For more information about IAM ARNs, see Using Identifiers.

CustomSecurityGroupIds.documentation: An array containing the layer custom security group IDs.

Packages.documentation: An array of Package objects that describe the layer packages.

NumberOfDisks.documentation: The number of disks in the volume.

VolumeConfigurations.documentation: A VolumeConfigurations object that describes the layer Amazon EBS volumes.

EnableAutoHealing.documentation: Whether to disable auto healing for the layer.

AutoAssignElasticIps.documentation: Whether to automatically assign an Elastic IP address to the layer.

Setup.documentation: An array of custom recipe names to be run following a setup event.

Configure.documentation: An array of custom recipe names to be run following a configure event.

Deploy.documentation: An array of custom recipe names to be run following a deploy event.

Undeploy.documentation: An array of custom recipe names to be run following a undeploy event.

Shutdown.documentation: An array of custom recipe names to be run following a shutdown event.

CustomRecipes.documentation: A LayerCustomRecipes object that specifies the layer custom recipes.

Region.documentation: The stack AWS region, such as "us-east-1". For more information about Amazon regions, see Regions and Endpoints.

Attributes.documentation: One or more user-defined key/value pairs to be added to the stack attributes bag.

ServiceRoleArn.documentation: The stack AWS Identity and Access Management (IAM) role, which allows OpsWorks to work with AWS resources on your behalf. You must set this parameter to the Amazon Resource Name (ARN) for an existing IAM role. For more information about IAM ARNs, see Using Identifiers.

DefaultOs.documentation:
The stack default operating system, which must be set to one of the following:

  • m1.small
  • m1.medium
  • m1.large
  • m1.xlarge
  • c1.medium
  • c1.xlarge
  • m2.xlarge
  • m2.2xlarge
  • m2.4xlarge

HostnameTheme.documentation: The stack host name theme, with spaces are replaced by underscores. For example: Bud_Spencer. By default, HostnameTheme is set to the role-based theme.

DefaultAvailabilityZone.documentation: The stack default Availability Zone. For more information, see Regions and Endpoints.

CustomJson.documentation:
A string that contains user-defined, custom JSON. It is used to override the corresponding default stack configuration JSON values. The string should be in the following format and must escape characters such as '"'.:

"{\"key1\": \"value1\", \"key2\": \"value2\",...}"

Url.documentation:
The source URI. For example, the source URI for the OpsWorks MySQL cookbook is: https://github.com/scalarium/cookbooks.git

For Github repositories, you can also use the "git://..." format. For example:

git://github.com/scalarium/cookbooks.git

Revision.documentation: The application's version. OpsWorks enables you to easily deploy new versions of an application. One of the simplest approaches is to have branches or revisions in your repository that represent different versions that can potentially be deployed.

DefaultSshKeyName.documentation: A default SSH key for the stack instances. You can override this value when you create or update an instance.

StackId.documentation: The stack ID, which is an opaque string that you use to identify the stack when performing actions such as DescribeStacks.

errors.documentation: Indicates that a resource was not found.

DeleteElasticIp.documentation: Whether to delete the instance Elastic IP address.

DeleteVolumes.documentation: Whether to delete the instance Amazon EBS volumes.

errors.documentation: Indicates that a resource was not found.

DeleteLayer.name: DeleteLayer

errors.documentation: Indicates that a resource was not found.

DeleteLayer.documentation: Deletes a specified layer. You must first remove all associated instances.

DeleteStack.name: DeleteStack

errors.documentation: Indicates that a resource was not found.

DeleteStack.documentation: Deletes a specified stack. You must first delete all instances and layers.

errors.documentation: Indicates that a resource was not found.

DescribeApps.name: DescribeApps

StackId.documentation: The app stack ID.

AppIds.documentation: An array of app IDs for the apps to be described.

Url.documentation:
The source URI. For example, the source URI for the OpsWorks MySQL cookbook is: https://github.com/scalarium/cookbooks.git

For Github repositories, you can also use the "git://..." format. For example:

git://github.com/scalarium/cookbooks.git

Revision.documentation: The application's version. OpsWorks enables you to easily deploy new versions of an application. One of the simplest approaches is to have branches or revisions in your repository that represent different versions that can potentially be deployed.

AppSource.documentation: A Source object that describes the app repository.

Domains.documentation: The app vhost settings, with multiple domains separated by commas. For example: 'www.mysite.com, mysite.com'

EnableSsl.documentation: Whether to enable SSL for the app.

Certificate.documentation: The contents of the certificate's domain.crt file.

PrivateKey.documentation: The private key; the contents of the certificate's domain.kex file.

Chain.documentation: Optional. Can be used to specify an intermediate certificate authority key or client authentication.

Attributes.documentation: The contents of the stack attributes bag.

Apps.documentation: An array of App objects that describe the specified apps.

errors.documentation: Indicates that a resource was not found.

DescribeApps.documentation: Requests a description of a specified set of apps.

CommandIds.documentation: An array of IDs for the commands to be described.

InstanceId.documentation: The ID of the instance where the command was executed.

Commands.documentation: An array of InstanceCommand objects that describe each of the specified commands.

errors.documentation: Indicates that a resource was not found.

DescribeDeployments.name: DescribeDeployments

DeploymentIds.documentation: An array of deployment IDs to be described.

Name.documentation:
Specifies the deployment operation. You can specify only one command.

For stacks, the available commands are:

  • ExecuteRecipes: Execute the recipes that are specified by the Args parameter.
  • InstallDependencies: Installs the stack's dependencies.
  • UpdateCustomCookbooks: Update the stack's custom cookbooks.
  • UpdateDependencies: Update the stack's dependencies.

For apps, the available commands are:

  • DeployApp: Deploy the app.
  • RollbackApp Roll the app back to the previous version. When you update an app, OpsWorks stores the previous version, up to a maximum of five versions. You can use this command to roll an app back as many as four versions.
  • StartApp: Start the app's web or application server.
  • StopApp: Stop the app's web or application server.
  • UndeployApp: Undeploy the app.

Args.documentation: An array of command arguments. This parameter is currently used only to specify the list of recipes to be executed by the ExecuteRecipes command.

CustomJson.documentation:
A string that contains user-defined custom JSON. It is used to override the corresponding default stack configuration JSON values for stack. The string should be in the following format and must escape characters such as '"'.:

"{\"key1\": \"value1\", \"key2\": \"value2\",...}"

members.documentation: Describes a deployment of a stack or app.

Deployments.documentation: An array of Deployment objects that describe the deployments.

errors.documentation: Indicates that a resource was not found.

DescribeDeployments.documentation: Requests a description of a specified set of deployments.

Ips.documentation: An array of Elastic IP addresses to be described.

Region.documentation: The AWS region. For more information, see Regions and Endpoints.

ElasticIps.documentation: An ElasticIps object that describes the specified Elastic IP addresses.

errors.documentation: Indicates that a resource was not found.

DescribeInstances.name: DescribeInstances

InstanceIds.documentation: An array of instance IDs to be described.

Ec2InstanceId.documentation: The ID of the associated Amazon EC2 instance.

LayerIds.documentation: An array containing the instance layer IDs.

SecurityGroups.documentation: An array containing the instance security group names.

InstanceType.documentation:
The instance type, which can be one of the following:

  • m1.small
  • m1.medium
  • m1.large
  • m1.xlarge
  • c1.medium
  • c1.xlarge
  • m2.xlarge
  • m2.2xlarge
  • m2.4xlarge

InstanceProfileArn.documentation: The instance IAM profile ARN. For more information about IAM ARNs, see Using Identifiers.

AvailabilityZone.documentation: The instance Availability Zone. For more information, see Regions and Endpoints.

AutoScalingType.documentation:
The instance's auto scaling type, which has three possible values:

  • AlwaysRunning: A 24x7 instance, which is not affected by auto scaling.
  • TimeBasedAutoScaling: A time-based auto scaling instance, which is started and stopped based on a specified schedule.
  • LoadBasedAutoScaling: A load-based auto scaling instance, which is started and stopped based on load metrics.

CreatedAt.documentation: The time that the instance was created.

LastServiceErrorId.documentation: The ID of the last service error. Call DescribeServiceErrors for details.

Instances.documentation: An array of Instance objects that describe the instances.

errors.documentation: Indicates that a resource was not found.

DescribeInstances.documentation: Requests a description of a specified set of instances.

DescribeLayers.name: DescribeLayers

LayerIds.documentation: An array of layer IDs that specify the layers to be described.

Type.documentation:
The layer type, which must be one of the following:

  • Custom
  • GangliaMonitoringMaster
  • HaProxy
  • MemcachedServer
  • MySqlMaster
  • NodeJsAppServer
  • PhpAppServer
  • RailsAppServer
  • WebServer

InstanceProfileArn.documentation: An IAM profile ARN for the layer's instances. For more information about IAM ARNs, see Using Identifiers.

DefaultSecurityGroupNames.documentation: An array containing the layer's security group names.

Packages.documentation: An array of Package objects that describe the layer's packages.

NumberOfDisks.documentation: The number of disks in the volume.

VolumeConfigurations.documentation: A VolumeConfigurations object that describes the layer's Amazon EBS volumes.

EnableAutoHealing.documentation: Whether auto healing is disabled for the layer.

AutoAssignElasticIps.documentation: Whether the layer has an automatically assigned Elastic IP address.

Setup.documentation: An array of custom recipe names to be run following a setup event.

Configure.documentation: An array of custom recipe names to be run following a configure event.

Deploy.documentation: An array of custom recipe names to be run following a deploy event.

Undeploy.documentation: An array of custom recipe names to be run following a undeploy event.

Shutdown.documentation: An array of custom recipe names to be run following a shutdown event.

Setup.documentation: An array of custom recipe names to be run following a setup event.

Configure.documentation: An array of custom recipe names to be run following a configure event.

Deploy.documentation: An array of custom recipe names to be run following a deploy event.

Undeploy.documentation: An array of custom recipe names to be run following a undeploy event.

Shutdown.documentation: An array of custom recipe names to be run following a shutdown event.

CustomRecipes.documentation: A LayerCustomRecipes object that specifies the layer's custom recipes.

Layers.documentation: An array of Layer objects that describe the layers.

errors.documentation: Indicates that a resource was not found.

DescribeLayers.documentation: Requests a description of one or more layers in a specified stack.

DescribeLoadBasedAutoScaling.name: DescribeLoadBasedAutoScaling

Enable.documentation: Whether load-based auto scaling is enabled for the layer.

InstanceCount.documentation: The number of instances to add or remove when the load exceeds a threshold.

ThresholdsWaitTime.documentation: The amount of time, in minutes, that the load must exceed a threshold before more instances are added or removed.

IgnoreMetricsTime.documentation: The amount of time (in minutes) after a scaling event occurs that OpsWorks should ignore metrics and not raise any additional scaling events. For example, OpsWorks adds new instances following an upscaling event but the instances won't start reducing the load until they have been booted and configured. There is no point in raising additional scaling events during that operation, which typically takes several minutes. IgnoreMetricsTime allows you to direct OpsWorks to not raise any scaling events long enough to get the new instances online.

CpuThreshold.documentation: The CPU utilization threshold, as a percent of the available CPU load.

MemoryThreshold.documentation: The memory utilization threshold, as a percent of the available memory.

LoadThreshold.documentation: The load threshold. For more information about how load is computed, see Load (computing).

UpScaling.documentation: A LoadBasedAutoscalingInstruction object that describes the upscaling configuration, which defines how and when OpsWorks increases the number of instances.

InstanceCount.documentation: The number of instances to add or remove when the load exceeds a threshold.

ThresholdsWaitTime.documentation: The amount of time, in minutes, that the load must exceed a threshold before more instances are added or removed.

IgnoreMetricsTime.documentation: The amount of time (in minutes) after a scaling event occurs that OpsWorks should ignore metrics and not raise any additional scaling events. For example, OpsWorks adds new instances following an upscaling event but the instances won't start reducing the load until they have been booted and configured. There is no point in raising additional scaling events during that operation, which typically takes several minutes. IgnoreMetricsTime allows you to direct OpsWorks to not raise any scaling events long enough to get the new instances online.

CpuThreshold.documentation: The CPU utilization threshold, as a percent of the available CPU load.

MemoryThreshold.documentation: The memory utilization threshold, as a percent of the available memory.

LoadThreshold.documentation: The load threshold. For more information about how load is computed, see Load (computing).

DownScaling.documentation: A LoadBasedAutoscalingInstruction object that describes the downscaling configuration, which defines how and when OpsWorks reduces the number of instances.

members.documentation: Describes a layer's load-based auto scaling configuration.

LoadBasedAutoScalingConfigurations.documentation: An array of LoadBasedAutoScalingConfiguration objects that describe each layer's configuration.

errors.documentation: Indicates that a resource was not found.

DescribeLoadBasedAutoScaling.documentation: Describes load-based auto scaling configurations for specified layers.

DescribePermissions.name: DescribePermissions

IamUserArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) for the stack AWS Identity and Access Management (IAM) role. For more information about IAM ARNs, see Using Identifiers.
The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) for an AWS Identity and Access Management (IAM) role. For more information about IAM ARNs, see Using Identifiers.

Permissions.documentation:
An array of Permission objects that describe the stack permissions.

  • If the request object contains only a stack ID, the array contains a Permission object with permissions for each of the stack IAM ARNs.
  • If the request object contains only an IAM ARN, the array contains a Permission object with permissions for each of the user's stack IDs.
  • If the request contains a stack ID and an IAM ARN, the array contains a single Permission object with permissions for the specified stack and IAM ARN.

errors.documentation: Indicates that a resource was not found.

DescribePermissions.documentation: Describes the permissions for a specified stack. You must specify at least one of the two request values.

RaidArrayIds.documentation: An array of RAID array IDs to be described.

NumberOfDisks.documentation: The number of disks in the array.

AvailabilityZone.documentation: The array's AWS Availability Zone. For more information, see Regions and Endpoints.

RaidArrays.documentation: A RaidArrays object that describes the specified RAID arrays.

errors.documentation: Indicates that a resource was not found.

ServiceErrorIds.documentation: An array of service error IDs to be described.

ServiceErrors.documentation: An array of ServiceError objects that describe the specified service errors.

errors.documentation: Indicates that a resource was not found.

SshKeyIds.documentation: An array of SSH key IDs to be described.

Region.documentation: The AWS region. For more information, see Regions and Endpoints.

SshKeys.documentation: An SshKeys object that describes the specified keys.

errors.documentation: Indicates that a resource was not found.

DescribeStacks.name: DescribeStacks

StackIds.documentation: An array of stack IDs that specify the stacks to be described.

Region.documentation: The stack AWS region, such as "us-east-1". For more information about AWS regions, see Regions and Endpoints.

Attributes.documentation: The contents of the stack's attributes bag.

ServiceRoleArn.documentation: The stack AWS Identity and Access Management (IAM) role.

DefaultOs.documentation:
The stack's default operating system, which must be set to one of the following:

  • m1.small
  • m1.medium
  • m1.large
  • m1.xlarge
  • c1.medium
  • c1.xlarge
  • m2.xlarge
  • m2.2xlarge
  • m2.4xlarge

HostnameTheme.documentation: The stack host name theme, with spaces replaced by underscores. For example: Bud_Spencer. By default, HostnameTheme is set to the role-based theme.

DefaultAvailabilityZone.documentation: The stack's default Availability Zone. For more information, see Regions and Endpoints.

CustomJson.documentation:
A string that contains user-defined, custom JSON. It is used to override the corresponding default stack configuration JSON values. The string should be in the following format and must escape characters such as '"'.:

"{\"key1\": \"value1\", \"key2\": \"value2\",...}"

Url.documentation:
The source URI. For example, the source URI for the OpsWorks MySQL cookbook is: https://github.com/scalarium/cookbooks.git

For Github repositories, you can also use the "git://..." format. For example:

git://github.com/scalarium/cookbooks.git

Revision.documentation: The application's version. OpsWorks enables you to easily deploy new versions of an application. One of the simplest approaches is to have branches or revisions in your repository that represent different versions that can potentially be deployed.

DefaultSshKeyName.documentation: A default SSH key for the stack's instances. You can override this value when you create or update an instance.

Stacks.documentation: An array of Stack objects that describe the stacks.

errors.documentation: Indicates that a resource was not found.

DescribeStacks.documentation: Requests a description of one or more stacks.

DescribeTimeBasedAutoScaling.name: DescribeTimeBasedAutoScaling

members.documentation: Describes an instance's time-based auto scaling configuration.

TimeBasedAutoScalingConfigurations.documentation: An array of TimeBasedAutoScalingConfiguration objects that describe the configuration for the specified instances.

errors.documentation: Indicates that a resource was not found.

DescribeTimeBasedAutoScaling.documentation: Describes time-based auto scaling configurations for specified instances.

IamUserArns.documentation: An array of IAM user ARNs that identify the users to be described.

UserProfiles.documentation: A Users object that describes the specified users.

errors.documentation: Indicates that a resource was not found.

VolumeIds.documentation: Am array of volume IDs to be described.

Status.documentation:
The volume status. The possible values are:

  • Ok
  • Impaired
  • Warning
  • Insufficient-data

Region.documentation: The AWS region. For more information about AWS regions, see Regions and Endpoints.

AvailabilityZone.documentation: The volume Availability Zone. For more information, see Regions and Endpoints.

errors.documentation: Indicates that a resource was not found.
Indicates that a resource was not found.

SetLoadBasedAutoScaling.name: SetLoadBasedAutoScaling

Enable.documentation: Enables load-based auto scaling for the layer.

InstanceCount.documentation: The number of instances to add or remove when the load exceeds a threshold.

ThresholdsWaitTime.documentation: The amount of time, in minutes, that the load must exceed a threshold before more instances are added or removed.

IgnoreMetricsTime.documentation: The amount of time (in minutes) after a scaling event occurs that OpsWorks should ignore metrics and not raise any additional scaling events. For example, OpsWorks adds new instances following an upscaling event but the instances won't start reducing the load until they have been booted and configured. There is no point in raising additional scaling events during that operation, which typically takes several minutes. IgnoreMetricsTime allows you to direct OpsWorks to not raise any scaling events long enough to get the new instances online.

CpuThreshold.documentation: The CPU utilization threshold, as a percent of the available CPU load.

MemoryThreshold.documentation: The memory utilization threshold, as a percent of the available memory.

LoadThreshold.documentation: The load threshold. For more information about how load is computed, see Load (computing).

UpScaling.documentation: An AutoScalingThresholds object with the upscaling threshold configuration. If the load exceeds these thresholds for a specified amount of time, OpsWorks starts a specified number of instances.

InstanceCount.documentation: The number of instances to add or remove when the load exceeds a threshold.

ThresholdsWaitTime.documentation: The amount of time, in minutes, that the load must exceed a threshold before more instances are added or removed.

IgnoreMetricsTime.documentation: The amount of time (in minutes) after a scaling event occurs that OpsWorks should ignore metrics and not raise any additional scaling events. For example, OpsWorks adds new instances following an upscaling event but the instances won't start reducing the load until they have been booted and configured. There is no point in raising additional scaling events during that operation, which typically takes several minutes. IgnoreMetricsTime allows you to direct OpsWorks to not raise any scaling events long enough to get the new instances online.

CpuThreshold.documentation: The CPU utilization threshold, as a percent of the available CPU load.

MemoryThreshold.documentation: The memory utilization threshold, as a percent of the available memory.

LoadThreshold.documentation: The load threshold. For more information about how load is computed, see Load (computing).

DownScaling.documentation: An AutoScalingThresholds object with the downscaling threshold configuration. If the load falls below these thresholds for a specified amount of time, OpsWorks stops a specified number of instances.

errors.documentation: Indicates that a resource was not found.

SetLoadBasedAutoScaling.documentation:
Specify the load-based auto scaling configuration for a specified layer.

To use load-based auto scaling, you must create a set of load-based auto scaling instances. Load-based auto scaling operates only on the instances from that set, so you must ensure that you have created enough instances to handle the maximum anticipated load.

AllowSsh.documentation: The user is allowed to use SSH to communicate with the instance.

AllowSudo.documentation: The user is allowed to use sudo to elevate privileges.

SetTimeBasedAutoScaling.name: SetTimeBasedAutoScaling

errors.documentation: Indicates that a resource was not found.

SetTimeBasedAutoScaling.documentation: Specify the time-based auto scaling configuration for a specified instance.

errors.documentation: Indicates that a resource was not found.

StartStack.name: StartStack

errors.documentation: Indicates that a resource was not found.

StartStack.documentation: Starts a specified stack.

StopInstance.name: StopInstance

errors.documentation: Indicates that a resource was not found.

StopInstance.documentation: Stops a specified instance. When you stop a standard instance, the data disappears and must be reinstalled when you restart the instance. You can stop an Amazon EBS-backed instance without losing data.

errors.documentation: Indicates that a resource was not found.

Url.documentation:
The source URI. For example, the source URI for the OpsWorks MySQL cookbook is: https://github.com/scalarium/cookbooks.git

For Github repositories, you can also use the "git://..." format. For example:

git://github.com/scalarium/cookbooks.git

Revision.documentation: The application's version. OpsWorks enables you to easily deploy new versions of an application. One of the simplest approaches is to have branches or revisions in your repository that represent different versions that can potentially be deployed.

AppSource.documentation: A Source object that specifies the app repository.

Domains.documentation: The app's virtual host settings, with multiple domains separated by commas. For example: 'www.mysite.com, mysite.com'

EnableSsl.documentation: Whether SSL is enabled for the app.

Certificate.documentation: The contents of the certificate's domain.crt file.

PrivateKey.documentation: The private key; the contents of the certificate's domain.kex file.

Chain.documentation: Optional. Can be used to specify an intermediate certificate authority key or client authentication.

Attributes.documentation: One or more user-defined key/value pairs to be added to the stack attributes bag.

errors.documentation: Indicates that a resource was not found.

InstanceType.documentation:
The instance type, which can be one of the following:

  • m1.small
  • m1.medium
  • m1.large
  • m1.xlarge
  • c1.medium
  • c1.xlarge
  • m2.xlarge
  • m2.2xlarge
  • m2.4xlarge

AutoScalingType.documentation:
The instance's auto scaling type, which has three possible values:

  • AlwaysRunning: A 24x7 instance, which is not affected by auto scaling.
  • TimeBasedAutoScaling: A time-based auto scaling instance, which is started and stopped based on a specified schedule.
  • LoadBasedAutoScaling: A load-based auto scaling instance, which is started and stopped based on load metrics.

errors.documentation: Indicates that a resource was not found.

Name.documentation: The layer name, which is used by the console.

Shortname.documentation: The layer short name, which is used internally by OpsWorks, by Chef. The shortname is also used as the name for the directory where your app files are installed. It can have a maximum of 200 characters and must be in the following format: /\A[a-z0-9\-\_\.]+\Z/.

Attributes.documentation: One or more user-defined key/value pairs to be added to the stack attributes bag.

InstanceProfileArn.documentation: An IAM profile ARN for the layer instances. You can override this value when you create an instance. For more information about IAM ARNs, see Using Identifiers.

CustomSecurityGroupIds.documentation: An array containing the layer's custom security group IDs.

Packages.documentation: An array of Package objects that describe the layer's packages.

NumberOfDisks.documentation: The number of disks in the volume.

VolumeConfigurations.documentation: A VolumeConfigurations object that describes the layer's Amazon EBS volumes.

EnableAutoHealing.documentation: Whether to disable auto healing for the layer.

AutoAssignElasticIps.documentation: Whether to automatically assign an Elastic IP address to the layer.

Setup.documentation: An array of custom recipe names to be run following a setup event.

Configure.documentation: An array of custom recipe names to be run following a configure event.

Deploy.documentation: An array of custom recipe names to be run following a deploy event.

Undeploy.documentation: An array of custom recipe names to be run following a undeploy event.

Shutdown.documentation: An array of custom recipe names to be run following a shutdown event.

CustomRecipes.documentation: A LayerCustomRecipes object that specifies the layer's custom recipes.

errors.documentation: Indicates that a resource was not found.

Attributes.documentation: One or more user-defined key/value pairs to be added to the stack attributes bag.

ServiceRoleArn.documentation: The stack AWS Identity and Access Management (IAM) role, which allows OpsWorks to work with AWS resources on your behalf. You must set this parameter to the Amazon Resource Name (ARN) for an existing IAM role. For more information about IAM ARNs, see Using Identifiers.

DefaultAvailabilityZone.documentation: The stack new default Availability Zone. For more information, see Regions and Endpoints.

CustomJson.documentation:
A string that contains user-defined, custom JSON. It is used to override the corresponding default stack configuration JSON values. The string should be in the following format and must escape characters such as '"'.:

"{\"key1\": \"value1\", \"key2\": \"value2\",...}"

Url.documentation:
The source URI. For example, the source URI for the OpsWorks MySQL cookbook is: https://github.com/scalarium/cookbooks.git

For Github repositories, you can also use the "git://..." format. For example:

git://github.com/scalarium/cookbooks.git

Revision.documentation: The application's version. OpsWorks enables you to easily deploy new versions of an application. One of the simplest approaches is to have branches or revisions in your repository that represent different versions that can potentially be deployed.

DefaultSshKeyName.documentation: A default SSH key for the stack instances. You can override this value when you create or update an instance.

errors.documentation: Indicates that a resource was not found.

UpdateUserProfile.name: UpdateUserProfile

errors.documentation: Indicates that a resource was not found.

UpdateUserProfile.documentation: Updates a specified user's SSH name and public key.
